author: dmitsuki
body:
They didn't. When I spoke to an Intel product lead around 2012 he told me flat out that Intel, as a company didn't even consider AMD competition. He said that the only focus on the company was fighting companies like Qualcomm. This was obvious with their push of things like Atom. They didn't care about HPC because they didn't see any competition in it. Almost all of the money and research was poured elsewhere because everybody went to them for HPC anyway. Once Ryzen was released, which had obvious buy signals about it at the time, they still didn't give a shit, because first gen wasn't as good as Intels established product. 

Then it got better.

Then it got even better.

Then it got even better.

And at that point it was too late, because Intel had focused all of it's energy trying to make atom processors and things of the like nobody wanted, they could no longer trivially keep up in HPC.

author: miscsubs
body:
On the earnings call they did mention the major cloud provider being a IFS packaging solutions customer but Pat himself talked about collaborative effort and I don’t know, it sounded a bigger deal at the time. But I guess they picked their words just right.

Still doesn’t justify the QCOM statement. At best, it was misleading IMO. that’s one thing that was frustrating about Intel in the previous regime. Always putting a spin on things with carefully crafted words.

author: Equivalent_Style4790
body:
I guess your study would show u that none are neither over nor underevaluated if u add some more parameter in it. 

- Microsoft and visa are there to last 
- apple have only 1 product  that made most of its revenue
- facebook and google are being fought by all the government for tax evasion and stuff. 
- qualcomm and intel are suffering the semiconducter crsis and they are only "supliers" and thus are heavily dependant on other big companies. 
- amazon was heavily sollicitaed during the pandemic and now ppl want to shop in the physical shops

I beleive that those ideas can provide some insight of why a stock is under or over evaluated. 

Not to mention how the pandemic made all the money flow being very "special" during the last year and thus, all the number that are related on it are not even remotly indicating "companie's health". 

Thx for sharing ur study with us

author: miscsubs
body:
I was cautiously optimistic about Gelsinger but this QCOM deal announcement did make me question things. Intel said QCOM to make chips in their foundries, QCOM then said no commitment yet, they’re just evaluating.

They also said they signed up a major cloud customer and sure, they did, but only for packaging (Amazon).

Not sure if they’re intentionally misleading or being sloppy but I don’t like it.
